Legal_Issue: Lawfulness and reasonableness of the issuance of a Disposal at Sea Permit in presence of TBTs
Governing_Law: International Convention on the Control of Harmful Anti-fouling Systems on Ships
Evidence_Assessment: Scientific opinions on TBT risks, compliance with Clean-up Standard, age and activity level of anti-fouling paint
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant (The Society) to demonstrate unreasonableness or illegality
Credibility_Factor: Scientific evidence regarding inactivity of TBTs due to age
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions must be lawful, reasonable, and within statutory authority
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure by Minister to consider a ban on TBTs and potential environmental harm
Key_Evidence_Considered: Clean-up Standard compliance, age and degradation of TBT-containing paint
Legal_Framework: CEPA and related regulations governing vessel pollution and disposal at sea
Defendant_Response: Permit issued in accordance with law and scientific assessment
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to quash the permit decision
Outcome: Application dismissed; costs awarded to Respondents
Legal_Provision: CEPA, Vessel Pollution Regulations, International Convention on the Control of Harmful Anti-fouling Systems on Ships

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over water encroachment on First Nations' lands due to structures built by PFRA
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the RCMP's decision not to lay trespass charges be subject to judicial review?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Judicial review principles, Aboriginal and treaty rights
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No evidence supports a treaty obligation for RCMP assistance or an Aboriginal right to preferential policing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Principles of judicial review and prosecutorial discretion
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged infringement of Aboriginal and treaty rights
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of flagrant impropriety or malicious prosecution
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Flagrant impropriety or conduct shocking the conscience
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Judicial review only permissible in cases of flagrant impropriety
Crimes.Application_Factor: RCMP consulted legal counsel and acted within discretion
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness / No interference without flagrant impropriety

Crimes.Violation_Type: Trespass by PFRA and SWA on reserve lands due to water control structures
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Trespass laws related to reserve lands
Crimes.Governing_Law: Aboriginal and treaty rights, police discretion, judicial review standards
Crimes.Application_Facts: First Nations requested RCMP investigation into alleged trespass
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging RCMP’s refusal to lay charges
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of RCMP authority and duty to enforce on reserve
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence supporting breach of fiduciary duties or treaty obligations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' claims not supported by evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review compelling RCMP to lay charges
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Enforcement of trespass laws on reserve lands
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Flagrant impropriety standard for reviewing prosecutorial discretion
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: High threshold requiring shocking or malicious conduct
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RCMP investigated thoroughly and provided reasoned decision

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over water encroachment on reserve lands due to structures built by PFRA and SWA
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the RCMP's decision not to lay trespass or mischief charges be subject to judicial review?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Code (mischief), principles of police discretion, judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RCMP reviewed evidence and sought legal advice
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to show flagrant impropriety
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claims of conflicted legal counsel not substantiated
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Police discretion immune from review absent flagrant impropriety
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Conduct must shock the conscience to warrant intervention
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to consider Aboriginal rights and improper legal consultation
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Criminal Code and administrative law principles
Crimes.Defendant_Response: RCMP provided detailed reasons for not laying charges
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to compel criminal charges
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of Criminal Code relating to mischief

Dispute_Type: Administrative law challenge regarding environmental permit issuance
Legal_Issue: Lawfulness and reasonableness of issuing a water permit under the Canada National Parks Act
Governing_Law: Canada National Parks Act, subsection 8(2); Canadian Environmental Assessment Act
Evidence_Assessment: Environmental assessment conducted, public consultation held, historical water usage data (1995–1998) reviewed, conservation measures evaluated
Decision_Outcome: Water permit upheld as lawful and reasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant (Mountain Parks Watershed Association) to demonstrate unreasonableness or illegality
Credibility_Factor: Parks Canada's expertise and adherence to legislative and procedural requirements
Legal_Rule: Ecological integrity is the first priority under subsection 8(2) of the Canada National Parks Act; environmental assessments required for significant projects
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged impairment of ecological integrity and inadequate public consultation
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed; decision found to be within acceptable range of outcomes
Key_Evidence_Considered: Historical water withdrawal data, environmental impact assessment, public consultation records, conservation measures
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, environmental law, statutory interpretation
Defendant_Response: Permit issued based on comprehensive assessment and compliance with legal requirements
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, environmental studies, regulatory records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside the water permit decision
Outcome: Application dismissed; permit upheld
Legal_Provision: Subsection 8(2), Canada National Parks Act; Canadian Environmental Assessment Act

Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over environmental protection obligations
Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in failing to identify critical habitat for the Greater Sage-Grouse as required by SARA
Evidence_Assessment: Active leks and nesting/brood-rearing habitats were identifiable using existing models and data
Decision_Outcome: The Minister's decision not to identify critical habitat was unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicants to demonstrate unreasonableness; met
Credibility_Factor: Scientific data and recovery models supporting habitat identification were credible and available
Legal_Rule: Under SARA, the Minister must identify critical habitat 'to the extent possible' based on the best available information
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to comply with statutory duty under SARA to identify critical habitat
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of active leks, nesting and brood-rearing areas, scientific models and habitat data
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation of SARA, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Minister argued that identifying critical habitat was not feasible due to insufficient data
Evidence_Type: Scientific data, ecological models, expert assessments
Remedy_Requested: Redrafting of the critical habitat section in the recovery strategy
Outcome: Judicial review granted; Minister required to redraft critical habitat section within a specified timeframe

Legal_Issue: Was the removal of Mr. Testawich from his elected position justified under the Duncan First Nation Election Regulations?
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence supported the alleged violation of Section 4(B)
Decision_Outcome: Removal decision was unreasonable and breached procedural fairness
Burden_of_Proof: On the Committee to justify removal
Credibility_Factor: Lack of written record and clear reasons affected credibility of the Committee's decision
Legal_Rule: The Regulations and procedural fairness principles govern election disputes, with decisions reviewed for reasonableness
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged violation of election regulations by contacting electors without consent
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim upheld in favor of Mr. Testawich
Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of evidence supporting Section 4(B) violation, lack of written record
Legal_Framework: Duncan First Nation Election Regulations, principles of procedural fairness
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (lack of written record), procedural omissions
Remedy_Requested: Reinstatement, back pay, nullification of by-election, costs
Outcome: Mr. Testawich reinstated as councillor, by-election nullified, awarded back pay and costs
Authority: Election Committee, subject to judicial review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Membership in a criminal organization under IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 37(1)(a)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Immigration Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Substantial evidence linking applicant to Shui Fong organization in Macau
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Reasonable grounds to believe
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: No counter-evidence presented by applicant
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Membership in an organization engaged in planned and organized criminal activity renders a person inadmissible
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged membership in Shui Fong involved in murder, extortion
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, international criminal equivalency
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No substantial rebuttal or expert evidence provided

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on criminal organization ties
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Adequacy of evidence disclosure and hearing process
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Evidence from book and article used; no expert testimony on Macau law
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Threat to public safety due to organized crime links
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Reasonable grounds to believe membership based on credible sources
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, principles of dual criminality and equivalency

Crimes.Crime_Name: Reasonable grounds to believe in involvement in indictable offences outside Canada
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to foreign criminal organization involvement
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Equivalency of foreign crimes to Canadian indictable offences
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Abundant evidence of Triad involvement; lack of explicit equivalency analysis
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Reasonable grounds to believe
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Crimes like murder are universally recognized
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Foreign criminal activity must be equivalent to Canadian indictable offences
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to conduct formal equivalency test
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged legal sufficiency of equivalency analysis
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certify question on equivalency to higher court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act due to organized criminality
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility over organized crime membership
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Existence of reasonable grounds to believe membership in criminal organization
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Strong evidence with no rebuttal from applicant
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Reasonable grounds to believe
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Global illegality of cited crimes supports inference
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Membership in organization engaged in planned criminal activity leads to inadmissibility
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Association with Macau-based Triads conducting serious crimes
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, international crime equivalence
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No effective challenge to evidence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Employment/Service Obligation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (liberty rights)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Section 7; Crown Liability and Proceedings Act; Federal Court Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for interlocutory injunction or stay in Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff voluntarily joined training program; release was discretionary; grievance process incomplete; no evidence of contractual obligation to grant leave
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to show serious issue arising under Section 7
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not explicitly challenged; focus on legal entitlement rather than credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 7 protects liberty, but no positive obligation on Crown to grant discretionary release; injunctive relief against Crown is restricted
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Serious issue to be tried; appropriateness of injunctive relief
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Denial of leave/voluntary release to pursue graduate studies
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Training agreement, request for leave, refusal by authorities, ongoing grievance procedure
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Charter rights vs. administrative discretion in military/service obligations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No legal or contractual obligation to release plaintiff; proper procedures followed
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Injunction or stay to prevent enforcement of duty reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Terms of service agreement under Medical Officer Training Plan
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Section 7; Crown Liability and Proceedings Act, Section 22
Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiff sought leave to pursue further studies; request denied; failed to report for duty
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Ongoing grievance process; premature judicial intervention
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over Charter claims and injunctive relief against Crown
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Service agreement, request for leave, denial letter, grievance filing
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of legal entitlement to release or breach of contract
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; decision based on legal interpretation
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Injunctive relief to prevent enforcement of duty reporting
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay or injunction based on alleged Charter violation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue under Section 7 of the Charter
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Serious issue to be tried standard
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal or contractual right to release; voluntary commitment; grievance process not exhausted

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Issue: Did the Member err by failing to consider the likelihood of applicants appearing for their refugee hearings?
Outcome: The Member erred by not considering refugee hearings in assessing flight risk. Case remitted for redetermination.
Application_Error: Failure to consider relevance of refugee hearings in flight risk assessment
Legal_Standard: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention

Application_Facts: Applicants wanted in China for fraud, seeking refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider ongoing proceedings in detention decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider active refugee claims as a factor in flight risk
Outcome: Case remitted for redetermination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of flight risk and alternatives to detention
Decision_Rationale: Focus on removal likelihood without considering refugee hearings was unreasonable

Legal_Issue: Did the Member err by failing to consider the likelihood of applicants appearing for their refugee hearings as part of the flight risk analysis?
Evidence_Assessment: Member focused solely on removal likelihood
Legal_Rule: ID must assess flight risk and alternatives to detention, including upcoming proceedings
Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous omission of relevant proceedings in flight risk analysis
Legal_Framework: IRPA and Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review
Redetermination by different ID member
Outcome: Case remitted for reassessment

Dispute_Type: Patent infringement dispute over chemical process equivalence
Legal_Issue: Whether Nu-Pharm's process is an obvious chemical equivalent of Abbott's '151 patent
Governing_Law: s. 6 of the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Procedural_Stage: Application for prohibition order to prevent regulatory approval
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits, cross-examinations, and patent documents were analyzed to assess chemical equivalence
Decision_Outcome: Abbott's application for a prohibition order was granted
Burden_of_Proof: On Abbott to justify allegations of non-infringement based on proven or assumed facts
Credibility_Factor: Evidence showing acetone is not essential for industrial-scale production supported Abbott's claim
Legal_Rule: A court must determine if allegations of non-infringement are justified under s. 6 of the PM(NOC) Regulations
Standard_of_Review: Factual and legal assessment of chemical equivalence based on knowledge at the time of the patent
Grounds_for_Claim: Nu-Pharm’s process uses higher temperatures without acetone, alleged as trivial variation
Outcome_on_Merits: Nu-Pharm’s process deemed an obvious chemical equivalent; infringement claim justified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Chemical process details, role of acetone, temperature variations, expert affidavits
Legal_Framework: Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Defendant_Response: Nu-Pharm argued their process did not infringe due to different conditions (no acetone, higher temperature)
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, expert testimony, patent specifications
Remedy_Requested: Prohibition order to block regulatory approval until patent expiry
Outcome: Prohibition order granted; Nu-Pharm barred from proceeding until patent expiration
Legal_Provision: s. 6, Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations

Crimes.Application_Facts: Male applicant previously deported from the USA returned without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of lawful entry or status documentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: U.S. conviction and deportation affecting Canadian refugee claim
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of legal re-entry or relief from inadmissibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged, but claim undermined by criminal history
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Prior conviction and illegal re-entry demonstrate criminal conduct incompatible with refugee protection
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court on review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act violations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee eligibility and exclusion under IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of Article 1F(b) exclusion for serious non-political crime
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Refugee Convention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of male applicant’s drug trafficking conviction and female applicant’s lack of evidence for persecution claims
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to establish well-founded fear and rebut exclusion grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Female applicant returned to country of origin, undermining subjective fear
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) excludes individuals convicted of serious non-political crimes
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by Colombian groups
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction records, return to Colombia, lack of documentary threats
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicants argued fear of persecution despite criminal history
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn of IRB decision through judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee status under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether drug trafficking constitutes a serious non-political crime
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for possession with intent to distribute, sentence served, fair trial confirmed
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to rebut presumption of seriousness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Criminal conviction not disputed
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) exclusion applies to serious non-political crimes regardless of political motivation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Claim of persecution fear despite criminal record
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: U.S. conviction, 27-month sentence, deportation, gravity of offense in Canada
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant did not present mitigating factors
Crimes.Authority: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court on review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection based on criminal conduct
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Fair hearing confirmed; no breach found
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Illegal re-entry into the USA following deportation
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of drug conspiracy in the USA
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Criminal activity unrelated to political persecution
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Seriousness of drug-related conspiracy and lack of mitigation

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration and Refugee Protection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether 'people smuggling' under IRPA s.37(1)(b) can be defined using s.117 of IRPA rather than an international instrument
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.37(1)(b)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant claimed invitee status due to ship escort; court found interception in Canadian waters negates such status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural fairness or legal error
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of evidence supporting invitee status
Crimes.Legal_Rule: IRPA s.37(1)(b) allows inadmissibility for people smuggling without criminality finding
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenged inadmissibility based on alleged people smuggling
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Location of interception (Canadian waters), nature of vessel approach
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued invitee status and need for criminality finding

Crimes.Crime_Name: No finding of criminality required for inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of immigration inadmissibility provisions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is a finding of criminality necessary for determining inadmissibility under section 37(1)(b) of IRPA?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant argued criminality must be established; court found statutory language clear
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show statutory misinterpretation
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – issue of law
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 37(1)(b) does not require a criminality finding for inadmissibility
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Claim that criminality must be proven for inadmissibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Text of IRPA, comparison with s.36(1)/(2)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued necessity of criminality finding
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court, citing Justice Simon Noël’s decision in IMM-4761-11

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on smuggling allegations
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether definition of 'people smuggling' should follow international instruments or domestic law
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Materials reviewed by court, arguments heard
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency / Immigration Division
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged facilitation of unauthorized entry into Canada
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: By vessel intercepted in Canadian waters
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No criminal finding made; irrelevant under s.37(1)(b)
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Interception within Canadian jurisdiction, lack of invitee status, statutory definition under s.117

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk to life
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Threats from non-state actor (former police commander)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistent testimony, lack of credible evidence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimants to prove inadequate state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Testimony found not credible due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Claimants must prove inability or unwillingness of state to protect
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of retaliation from former police commander
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, refugee protection provisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged RPD's assessment of state protection

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistent and not credible testimony
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of credibility in allegations of corruption and threats
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Claimants must prove state protection is inadequate
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Threats from former police official and systemic corruption
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian refugee law and administrative law principles
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued corruption prevented effective protection
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question or overturning RPD decision
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed, no question for certification

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD’s finding on state protection availability
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Weighed conflicting evidence on Mexico's security efforts
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate inadequate protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Concerns about credibility but focus on systemic issues
Crimes.Legal_Rule: State protection must be inadequate despite existing challenges
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution by non-state agents and insufficient state response
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law standards applied to RPD decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Contested adequacy of state protection due to inefficiency

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD’s conclusion on state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Focused on both government efforts and operational realities
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Clear and convincing evidence required to show inadequate protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Testimony inconsistent and deemed not credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Claimants must demonstrate state is unable or unwilling to protect
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Threats from former police commander and bribery demands
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee law and reasonableness standard in administrative review
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued RPD overemphasized government efforts

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection amid systemic corruption
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Found testimony inconsistent and lacking credibility
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to provide clear evidence of inadequate protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Allegations undermined by inconsistent accounts
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Presumption of state protection unless clearly rebutted
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Systemic corruption and targeted threats from ex-police commander
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Feared reporting due to bribery and corruption
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed, no question for certification

Dispute_Type: Patent infringement dispute between brand-name and generic drug manufacturers
Legal_Issue: Whether the generic drug manufacturers infringed the '380 Patent for lovastatin
Governing_Law: Section 5 and Section 6 of the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under the Patent Act and associated regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Applicants' contamination argument rejected; evidence showed Coniothyrium fuckelii alone produced significant yield improvements; sterilization procedures deemed adequate
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicants to show that non-infringement allegations were justified
Credibility_Factor: Applicants' allegations found unjustified on a balance of probabilities
Legal_Rule: Section 5 and 6 of the Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations govern allegations of non-infringement and prohibition orders
Grounds_for_Claim: Merck Frosst claimed generic manufacturers would infringe their patent by producing lovastatin using Coniothyrium fuckelii
Outcome_on_Merits: Respondents' non-infringement allegations justified; applications dismissed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Yield data from Coniothyrium fuckelii; adequacy of sterilization procedures; absence of Aspergillus terreus contamination
Legal_Framework: Patent Act, Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Defendant_Response: Generic manufacturers alleged non-infringement based on contamination claims and alternative production methods
Evidence_Type: Scientific and technical evidence, process documentation, microbiological data
Remedy_Requested: Prohibition orders against generic manufacturers to prevent market entry
Outcome: Applications dismissed; costs awarded to respondents
Legal_Provision: Section 5 and 6, Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Authority: Federal Court (implied by judicial review under Patent Act)

Legal_Issue: Whether the application is moot after the applicant's removal to their country of nationality
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant was deported to Slovakia, failed to contact the court, did not appoint a representative
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate live controversy
Legal_Rule: Under the Borowski test for mootness, an application is moot if there is no live controversy or adversarial context
Grounds_for_Claim: Removal to country of nationality, lack of contact with court
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case dismissed on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Deportation to Slovakia, lack of communication from applicant
Legal_Framework: Borowski test for mootness
Evidence_Type: Official deportation records, lack of correspondence
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of immigration decision
Outcome: Application dismissed, no certification question or cost award

Crime_Name: Trademark Infringement and Breach of Contract
Dispute_Type: Termination of franchise agreement and continued use of trademarks
Legal_Issue: Whether plaintiffs can obtain an interlocutory injunction for trademark infringement and false representation
Evidence_Assessment: Huron Shores ceased paying fees; dispute over termination notice and compliance
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs must show serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Both parties presented credible arguments on the validity of termination and rights to use trademarks
Legal_Rule: Interlocutory injunction requires: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience favoring applicant
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark infringement post-termination, breach of contract, false representation
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided; case remains open for full trial
Key_Evidence_Considered: Franchise agreement terms, payment history, notice of termination, use of trademarks
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, common law principles of contract and injunctions
Defendant_Response: Claimed breach of contract by plaintiff and sought specific performance
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (contract), financial records, legal notices
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to stop trademark use
Outcome: Injunction denied; status quo maintained with Huron Shores depositing 1.5% of gross income or $3,000 into trust account
Legal_Provision: Registered trademark protections, contractual termination clauses
Authority: Court applying equitable doctrines including 'clean hands'

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious non-political crime under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted in Romania for accepting a bribe, punishable by 3-12 years; equivalent Canadian offense carries up to 14 years under Criminal Code s. 120
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Applicant fled Romania and sought status in Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Claimed political persecution but was convicted of bribery
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conviction record from Romania, credibility assessment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting claim of being framed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of being framed found implausible due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Conviction equivalent to offense with maximum sentence over ten years in Canada; lack of credibility in defense

Crimes.Crime_Name: Bribery under the Criminal Code of Canada
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee status
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant committed a serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board assessed inconsistencies in applicant's testimony
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility for protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claim of being framed deemed implausible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged political persecution after bribery conviction
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Foreign conviction, lack of corroborating evidence for framing claim
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed he was framed

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Claimed political persecution after corruption conviction
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refugee Protection Division decision reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Not applicable – exclusion based on criminal conduct
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Risk of persecution claimed but outweighed by criminal exclusion
Crimes.Credibility: Claim of being framed not credible

Legal_Issue: Whether Novopharm's proposed drug infringes Biovail's patents ('320 and '754) for Wellbutrin(r) SR
Governing_Law: Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations, SOR/93-133
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Notice of Allegation
Evidence_Assessment: Experts agreed HPMC and HPC are similar but differ on whether HPMC is essential; court found HPMC essential to '320 patent claims, excluding HPC as a variant; '754 patent disclosure focused on osmotic systems, not hydrogel processes
Decision_Outcome: Biovail's application dismissed; Novopharm does not infringe either patent
Burden_of_Proof: On Novopharm to justify allegations in Notice of Allegation
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony evaluated; court applied purposive construction principles
Legal_Rule: Purposive construction of patent claims; determination without final decision on validity or infringement
Standard_of_Review: Justification of allegations in Notice of Allegation
Grounds_for_Claim: Biovail alleged that Novopharm’s generic version of Wellbutrin(r) SR infringed its '320 and '754 patents
Outcome_on_Merits: No infringement found; Biovail’s attempt to block regulatory approval failed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Patent claims, expert testimony on polymer use (HPMC vs HPC), technological process differences (osmotic vs hydrogel)
Legal_Framework: Patent law, PM(NOC) Regulations, purposive claim construction
Defendant_Response: Novopharm challenged the validity and applicability of Biovail's patents via Notice of Allegation
Evidence_Type: Expert testimony, patent documents, chemical and process comparisons
Remedy_Requested: Biovail sought to prevent Novopharm from obtaining regulatory approval for generic Wellbutrin(r) SR
Outcome: Novopharm can proceed with drug development without waiting for patent expiration
Legal_Provision: SOR/93-133, Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Authority: Federal Court (implied by procedural context of NOC proceedings)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Public service employment and disciplinary action
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a public servant compel the Crown to accept resignation to avoid disciplinary consequences?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Federal Court review of dismissal and severance claim
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Resignation submitted during investigation, subsequent criminal charges
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to establish entitlement to severance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff's attempt to resign mid-investigation viewed as self-serving
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 26 of the Public Service Employment Act; equitable principle against profiting from wrongdoing
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Claim for severance pay based on alleged effective resignation
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to public policy
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of resignation, criminal charges, employer's refusal
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Refused resignation and dismissed for cause

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Public service employment and disciplinary action
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a public servant benefit from resignation after being charged with theft and fraud?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Federal Court review of severance entitlement
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Resignation during investigation, later criminal charges
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to prove right to severance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Attempt to resign to avoid dismissal seen as improper
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Public policy prevents profiting from one's own wrong
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Entitlement to severance upon resignation
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Charges of theft and fraud, timing of resignation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Rejected resignation and discharged for cause
Crimes.Outcome: Claim dismissed, costs awarded to defendant

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of trust by public officer
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Public service misconduct and resignation attempt
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a public servant benefit from resignation to avoid discharge for cause?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Declaratory relief sought in Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Misconduct under investigation, criminal charges pending
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to establish lawful resignation and entitlement
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Suspension and criminal charges undermined credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 26 of the Public Service Employment Act; public policy against benefiting from wrongdoing
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Judicial discretion guided by public policy
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Declaration of entitlement to severance pay
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected to prevent encouragement of illegality
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of charges (theft, fraud, breach of trust), refusal of resignation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Refused resignation and proceeded with dismissal

Risk_Assessment: The Applicants claimed inadequate state protection due to criminal intimidation and sexual assault
Evidence_Type: Self-reported claims, lack of official documentation
Evidence_Credibility: Questioned due to failure to report or seek help
Credibility_Assessment: Low – no engagement with authorities or alternate agencies
Legal_Provision: Rule: Individuals must reasonably exhaust domestic protective options before seeking international protection

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in its treatment of evidence concerning state protection?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Assessment: Applicants failed to report multiple incidents
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to show lack of state protection
Credibility_Factor: Failure to report incidents or seek help from agencies
Legal_Rule: Individuals must attempt to access state protection before seeking international protection
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of state protection in Mexico
Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of reporting, availability of Mexican human rights bodies
Legal_Framework: Functioning democracy presumes state protection unless rebutted
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of refugee claim rejection
Outcome: Dismissed

Targeted_Victimization: Alleged targeted victimization due to personal circumstances
Evidence_Credibility: Undermined by lack of corroboration or reporting
Credibility_Assessment: Low – no engagement with state protection mechanisms
Legal_Provision: Rule: Must show substantial evidence to rebut presumption of state protection

Legal_Issue: Whether subjective reluctance can rebut presumption of state protection
Evidence_Assessment: No reports made to authorities or alternate agencies
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unavailability of protection
Credibility_Factor: Failure to report kidnapping, intimidation, or seek employer/agency help
Legal_Rule: Cannot rely on subjective reluctance in a functioning democracy
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of criminal elements due to past incidents
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of state efforts despite systemic issues
Legal_Framework: Presumption of effective state protection
Evidence_Type: Affidavits, lack of police or institutional records
Remedy_Requested: Overturn of refugee claim denial
Outcome: Application dismissed

Risk_Assessment: Risks arising from involvement in an armed robbery case
Targeted_Victimization: Alleged targeting due to cooperation or exposure
Evidence_Sufficiency: Limited – no formal reports or follow-up actions
Evidence_Credibility: Questionable due to lack of verification
Credibility_Assessment: Low – no engagement with protection systems
Legal_Provision: Rule: Must attempt to access state protection services before seeking international protection

Dispute_Type: Jurisdictional dispute in patent infringement case
Legal_Issue: Whether the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, has jurisdiction to hear a patent infringement case against the Province of Ontario
Decision_Outcome: Motion to strike granted; Federal Court lacks jurisdiction
Legal_Rule: Section 5 of the Proceedings Against the Crown Act (Ont.) allows tort actions against the provincial Crown but confines them to Ontario courts
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged patent infringement by the Province of Ontario
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case dismissed on jurisdictional grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Relevant statutes and case law regarding jurisdiction
Legal_Framework: Provincial and federal legislative framework governing suits against the Crown
Defendant_Response: Ontario moved to strike the action due to lack of jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Adjudication of patent infringement in Federal Court
Outcome: Action struck out; plaintiffs cannot sue Ontario in the Federal Court
Legal_Provision: Section 5, Proceedings Against the Crown Act (Ont.)
Authority: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division

Crime_Name: Deportation of a Bisexual Individual to Potential Harm
Dispute_Type: Whether removal to Nigeria poses risk due to sexual orientation
Legal_Issue: Can the removal be stayed based on potential harm due to sexual orientation?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application with motion for stay
Evidence_Assessment: Credible evidence of increased risks for LGBTQ+ individuals in Nigeria post-decision
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must show serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, and favorable balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Officer incorrectly deemed risk unchanged; applicant's fear considered credible
Legal_Rule: Tripartite test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context of administrative decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to sexual orientation and worsening conditions in Nigeria
Outcome_on_Merits: Stay of removal ordered until underlying application is resolved
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conditions for LGBTQ+ individuals in Nigeria, post-decision developments, personal circumstances of Mr. Abioye
Legal_Framework: Federal Court jurisdiction, immigration and refugee protection laws
Defendant_Response: Risk assessment deemed unchanged by the Officer
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, country condition reports, personal testimony
Remedy_Requested: Stay of removal pending resolution of judicial review
Outcome: Stay granted
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, relevant sections on risk assessment and stay of removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Disclose Material Facts in Immigration Context
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration Application Dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in visa refusal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Extrinsic evidence from employer (Plastik) used without notification
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant, but procedural fairness obligations on decision maker
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's employment history questioned without opportunity to respond
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Visa officers must provide opportunity to respond to extrinsic evidence, consider all relevant work experience, and notify of language assessment changes
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No response opportunity provided to applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, third-party verification, application forms
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of refusal decision and re-determination
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA relating to procedural fairness and assessment criteria

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration Application Dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and accuracy of information in visa assessment
Crimes.Outcome: Decision overturned and referred back for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant not given chance to explain discrepancies
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on truthfulness and procedural fairness
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of unverified extrinsic evidence without notice
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of notification regarding language requirements and employment verification
Crimes.Application_Error: Overlooking relevant work experience and applying new language rules without notice
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Compliance with procedural fairness under administrative law
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to inform and provide fair opportunity to respond
Crimes.Application_Factor: Work experience and language proficiency scoring
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged inconsistencies in employment verification, no finding of intentional fraud

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration Application Dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and allegations of misrepresentation
Crimes.Outcome: Decision overturned and referred to different visa officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant not informed of concerns or allowed to address discrepancies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employer verification, job description documents, language test requirements
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections on misrepresentation and procedural rights
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Unfair reliance on unverified evidence and failure to disclose regulatory changes
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to notify applicant of new language requirements and disregard of relevant experience
Crimes.Application_Error: Incorrect application of scoring criteria and assessment rules
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and accurate application of immigration rules
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Researcher/tutor role deemed relevant but excluded
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to ensure fairness in assessment process
Crimes.Application_Factor: Work experience evaluation and language proficiency
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No direct finding of fraud; issues centered on process and communication

Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed

Internal flight alternative

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and substantive reasonableness of visa denial

Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate error in decision
Credibility_Factor: Doubt regarding applicant's intent to return to Romania
Legal_Rule: Visa officers have discretion to refuse applications based on qualifications and intent to return; no requirement for personal interview unless procedural fairness demands it
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged procedural unfairness and unreasonable decision-making
Key_Evidence_Considered: IPO report, applicant's lack of relevant experience, financial situation, stated purpose of travel

Remedy_Requested: Certification of additional questions and overturning of visa denial

Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution risk in India and China, previously denied asylum in the USA, sought refugee protection in Canada
Claimant_Status: Stateless, claimed entitlement to Indian citizenship but not recognized by India, not considered a citizen of China
Procedural_Issue: RPD's decision contained contradictory findings on citizenship
Remanded for re-determination by a different panel
Jurisdictional_Issue: Interpretation of foreign law (Indian citizenship law) by RPD
Evidence_Used: Evidence that India does not recognize Tibetans as citizens
Lack of proof that China would interpret Indian law as granting citizenship
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to support conclusion that Applicant was entitled to Indian citizenship
Decision_Outcome: RPD found Applicant not a citizen of China
Outcome: Judicial review allowed
Decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee status by a different RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in interpreting foreign law
Decision_Rationale: RPD's conclusion was unreasonable due to internal contradictions regarding citizenship status and lack of supporting evidence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration application refusal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, immigration status history, refugee claim outcome
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Illegal employment and residence after refugee claim denial
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Discretionary evaluation of humanitarian and compassionate factors
Crimes.Application_Factor: Self-sufficiency achieved through illegal means not a positive factor
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation related to immigration status and employment authorization

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether unauthorized work is a relevant consideration in humanitarian applications
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Continued unauthorized work despite notice to cease
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Work history, immigration status documentation, family ties in Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on adaptation and family
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Unauthorized employment as a negative factor
Crimes.Application_Error: No error in considering unauthorized work
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of legal self-sufficiency despite integration efforts
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not applicable directly, but linked to false representation of status

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remained in Canada after loss of status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 114(2) of IRPA – failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after refugee claim denial and worked illegally
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimants without valid immigration status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Continued presence and work without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Application assessed under H&C provisions despite lack of status
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Officer had authority to assess H&C application despite unlawful stay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Duration of stay, family connections, employment history, financial independence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate unusual hardship or exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative inference from continued illegal presence and work
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application refused; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Outcome: Applicants required to leave Canada or reapply from abroad
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary fairness and reasonableness under H&C framework
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Illegal actions cannot form the basis of a successful humanitarian claim

Application_Facts: Failures in managing mineral rights by the Crown, specifically related to fiduciary duties concerning mineral rights surrendered in the 1940s
Procedural_Issue: Motion for leave to amend the Statement of Claim
Decision_Outcome: Amendments allowed under Rule 201 as they arise from substantially the same facts as the original claim
Outcome: Amendments permitted; no prejudice to defendant; costs awarded appropriately
Relief_Sought: To include new particulars or causes of action in the Statement of Claim
Remedy_Sought: Leave to amend the Statement of Claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Rule 201 of the Federal Court Rules
Decision_Rationale: The amendments are allowed because they arise from substantially the same facts as the original claim and serve the interests of justice, despite potential limitation period concerns

Dispute_Type: Credibility and plausibility of refugee claim
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in dismissing the refugee claim based on credibility, plausibility, and internal flight alternative
Outcome: Application dismissed, no certification question
Credibility_Assessment: Board found inconsistencies in testimony and doubted fear of persecution
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged persecution by wife's family in Pakistan
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Internal flight alternative (Rawalpindi or Kasur considered safe)
Application_Error: Errors in rejecting corroborative evidence and assessing Najma's emotional state
Evidence_Ignored: Corroborative evidence, aspects of Najma's emotional state
Application_Factor: Fear of persecution, availability of safe relocation within country
Decision_Outcome: Dismissal upheld due to reasonable internal flight alternative finding

Legal_Issue: Did the citizenship judge make unreasonable factual findings regarding Mr. Suleiman's residency in Canada?
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no costs awarded
Credibility_Assessment: The judge deemed Mr. Suleiman credible after a hearing
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged factual errors in the citizenship judge's approval of Mr. Suleiman's application
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Minor discrepancies in evidence were found immaterial
Sufficiency of reasons provided by the judge
Application_Error: None found; decision upheld as reasonable

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Crimes.Outcome: Board erred in law by applying Article 1(F)(a) without sufficient evidence

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion upheld despite legal error due to credibility findings

Crimes.Credibility: Credibility issues reasonably addressed by the Board

Legal_Issue: Can the Board determine a foreign national is not a spouse without assessing marriage genuineness?
Outcome: The Board's decision was reasonable and did not require genuineness determination.
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies and lack of evidence for common interests
Evidence_Type: Lack of evidence for common interests
Basis_of_Claim: Marriage was for immigration purposes or not genuine
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed, no question certified for appeal

Application_Facts: Election invalidated due to irregularities affecting results; applicants ceased to hold office unless explicitly stated otherwise; governance gap risked
Procedural_Issue: Appeal arbitrator found irregularities; respondents moved for receiver/manager appointment
Evidence_Used: Findings of appeal arbitrator on election irregularities
Decision_Outcome: Election invalidated; applicants ceased to hold office
Outcome: Receiver-manager appointed
Remedy_Sought: Ensure proper governance until new elections
Legal_Standard_Applied: Under CER, officials cease to hold office if election is invalidated unless otherwise stated
Decision_Rationale: To maintain electoral integrity and prevent governance gap

Legal_Issue: Whether applicants remain in office after election ordered to be redone due to infractions
Evidence_Assessment: Arbitrator found infractions affecting election results
Legal_Rule: Officials hold office until appeal determines invalidity; receiver may be appointed if just or convenient
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of harm to SRFN members due to lack of valid governance
Legal_Framework: CER and Federal Courts Act
Defendant_Response: Applicants argue they remain in office under custom
Remedy_Requested: Appointment of receiver-manager
Outcome: Motion granted; Browning Crocker Inc. appointed
Legal_Provision: CER s. 3.4(b), s. 15.9.3; Federal Courts Act s. 44

Dispute_Type: Validity of SRFN Council following election irregularities
Legal_Issue: Existence of governance gap requiring receiver/manager appointment
Procedural_Stage: Post-invalidation of election; motion for interim management
Evidence_Assessment: Only three councillors remained, lacking quorum; evidence of potential misuse of funds
Legal_Rule: If election infractions materially affect results, prior results are invalidated and new election required
Grounds_for_Claim: Invalidation of election; risk of harm from continued governance by invalidated officials
Key_Evidence_Considered: Number of remaining councillors, affidavits, legal arguments
Legal_Framework: CER and Federal Courts Act
Defendant_Response: Applicants argue continuity of leadership per custom
Remedy_Requested: Appointment of receiver-manager
Outcome: Motion granted; Browning Crocker Inc. appointed until new election

Dispute_Type: Governance gap due to invalidated election and fund misuse
Legal_Issue: Appointment of receiver/manager due to election invalidation under CER
Procedural_Stage: Post-invalidation of 2008 election; pre-new election phase
Evidence_Assessment: Only three councillors remained; risk of fund misuse by invalid council
Legal_Rule: CER s. 15.9.3 mandates new election if infractions affect results; s. 44 permits receiver if just or convenient
Grounds_for_Claim: Invalidation of 2008 election; need to protect band funds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Arbitrator's finding of infractions, number of remaining councillors
Legal_Framework: CER and Federal Courts Act
Remedy_Requested: Appointment of receiver-manager
Outcome: Motion granted; Browning Crocker Inc. appointed until June 29, 2009 election

Application_Facts: Alexandr Pikulin claimed asylum due to alleged persecution in Israel; the Refugee Protection Division rejected his claim
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to analyze credibility and subjective fear of persecution; inadequate assessment of state protection and nature of persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of applicant's credibility and subjective fear; lack of proper evaluation of state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Inadequate credibility assessment by the tribunal
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded for reconsideration by a different panel
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim with proper credibility and fear assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Justified, transparent, intelligible decision within acceptable range based on facts and law
Decision_Rationale: Decision lacked sufficient reasoning on credibility, subjective fear, state protection, and persecution

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed Convention refugee status based on past persecution in Chile; Tribunal accepted credible evidence of past persecution but dismissed claim due to changed country conditions without addressing s. 2(3)
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to consider s. 2(3) despite evidence of past persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess compelling reasons arising from past persecution under s. 2(3)
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant's evidence was found credible
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed based on changed country conditions
Outcome: Judicial review allowed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 2(3) of the Immigration Act regarding continued refugee status despite changed country conditions
Decision_Rationale: The Tribunal erred in law by not considering s. 2(3) which requires assessment of compelling reasons arising from past persecution

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Erroneous standard of proof for IFA

Perpetrator_Type: Police officer linked to criminal gang

Victim_Status: Business employee targeted due to job

Risk_Assessment: Specific personal risk due to employment

Procedural_Issue: RAD failed to conduct independent assessment of credibility; improperly relied on RPD findings
Jurisdictional_Issue: No jurisdictional error identified; issue pertains to standard of review
Evidence_Used: RPD's credibility findings, applicant's testimony, country condition reports
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible; RAD did not independently reassess
Decision_Outcome: RAD upheld RPD's negative credibility finding
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision quashed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee, protection from removal
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim by a new RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: RAD incorrectly applied reasonableness by deferring to RPD without independent analysis; burden improperly placed on applicant

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality under IRPA
Legal_Issue: Jurisdiction of IAD to hear constitutional challenges
Legal_Rule: Sections 64 and 190 remove appeal rights for permanent residents inadmissible due to serious criminality
Grounds_for_Claim: Constitutional challenge under Charter
Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of IAD decision
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; IAD lacks jurisdiction

Legal_Issue: Existence of Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Mexico City
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), particularly sections relating to Convention refugee status
Outcome: RPD's decision overturned; case remanded for re-determination by a different panel
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' fear of persecution in Durango found credible
Evidence_Type: Testimony of applicants, report from ombudsman on state-cartel collusion in Mexico
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of IRPA – Criteria for Convention refugee definition
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to links between state officials and drug cartels
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) within Mexico
Proceeding_Type: Refugee protection claim before the Refugee Protection Division (RPD)
Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), later reviewed by Federal Court
Application_Error: Speculative finding of IFA without sufficient evidence
Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution under the 1951 Refugee Convention
Evidence_Ignored: Ombudsman’s report indicating widespread state-cartel collaboration across Mexico
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of RPD's decision on judicial review
Application_Factor: Geographic internal relocation within home country
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed by RPD, later set aside by Federal Court
